variant.question: During the cross-check before entering NAT HLA airspace, what is the limitation on the difference between the two primary altimeters?
During operations in the NAT HLA, certain reports are made automatically by the aircraft systems. However, pilots must also make reports. Which of the following must pilots report?

options.text: Horizontal wind shear, jetstreams.
Moderate or severe turbulence in an area where turbulence has been forecasted.
The difference in the forecasted wind and temperature.
Severe turbulence, severe icing, volcanic ash.

variant.question: For full access to the NAT HLA, the minimum navigation specification approved by the state of registry or the state of the operator is:

options.text: RNP 1.
RNP 10 or RNP 4.
RNP 3.
RNP 5.

variant.question: An aircraft is entering the NAT. The tolerance of the boundary window is:

options.text: 3 minutes.
5 minutes.
3 minutes, but only between FL290 and FL390.
No boundary window required.

variant.question: The abbreviation "OTS" stands for:

options.text: Omni-directional Track Selector.
Organised Track System.
Oceanic Traffic Separation.
Oceanic Track System.

variant.question: In MNPS airspace, in case of need to establish communication with nearby aircraft, the backup inter-pilot air-to-air VHF frequency is:
The climb or descent through MNPS airspace of a non-MNPS certified aircraft:

options.text: Can be authorised when the aircraft has two long range navigation systems.
Is forbidden in all circumstances.
Can be authorised under radar control if the pilot is in VHF contact with the controller.
Can be authorised only if the pilot is in communication with the pilot of the conflicting aircraft.

variant.question: In accordance with OPS regulations, regarding the first aid oxygen, the quantity of undiluted oxygen carried on board a pressurised aeroplane with 8 passengers operated at pressure altitude 27000 ft, shall be sufficient for at least:

options.text: 2 passengers for the remainder of the flight after cabin depressurisation when the cabin altitude only exceeds 14000 ft.
1 passenger for the remainder of the flight after cabin depressurisation when the cabin altitude exceeds 8000 ft.
1 passenger for the remainder of the flight after cabin depressurisation when the cabin altitude only exceeds 14000 ft.
2 passengers for the remainder of the flight after cabin depressurisation when the cabin altitude exceeds 8000 ft.

variant.question: The minimum lateral separation to be maintained between aircraft flying in MNPS airspace is:

options.text: 60 NM.
90 NM.
30 NM.

variant.question: Clearance limit is a point:

options.text: from which a specific clearance is valid.
where an airway clearance is amended.
to which a specific clearance is valid and this point is determined by PIC.
to which a specific clearance is valid.

variant.question: The 24 hour period commences at \_\_\_\_\_ in a local time.
When flying within the NAT HLA, the minimum required means of contacting ATC is by using…

options.text: VHF communications in the 118.000 MHz to 136.975 MHz frequency band.
HF communications in the 2.8 MHz to 18 MHz frequency band.
CPDLC using either satellite or HF single sideband.
Data link through the ACARS or ATN.

variant.question: In accordance with OPS regulations, an aeroplane whose maximum take-off mass exceeds 5 700 kg or whose maximum approved passenger seating configuration is greater than 9 seats and less than 200 seats must be equipped with:

options.text: one crash axe on the flight deck and one crowbar in the passenger compartment.
one crowbar on the flight deck and one crash axe in the passenger compartment.
one crash axe or crowbar on the flight deck.
one crash axe and one crowbar in the passenger compartment.

variant.question: An accurately aligned Inertial Reference System (IRS) will prevent navigation system errors being introduced when planning to fly into the North Atlantic High Level Airspace (NAT HLA). This system should be put into the "Align Mode" in order to achieve optimum performance:

options.text: At cruising level, at least 40 minutes before reaching the boundary of the oceanic airspace.
As soon as possible - normally when the first crew member enters the flight deck.
As soon as all the engines of the aircraft have been started.
After parking brakes have been released.

variant.question: Who provides service within the Northern Oceanic Transition Area (NOTA) and Shannon Oceanic Transition Area (SOTA)?

options.text: NOTA: Shanwick ACA; SOTA: Shannon Control
NOTA: Shanwick ACA; SOTA: Shanwick ACA
NOTA: Shanwick ACA; NOTA: Shannon Control
NOTA: Shannon Control; SOTA: Shannon Control

variant.question: An aircraft wishes to fly the PBCS routes in the NAT HLA. What are the requirements?

options.text: 3 LRNS.
ADS-C and CPDLC.
Increased RVSM capability.
No special requirements.

variant.question: During the passenger service, moderate turbulence is experienced. What shall cabin crew do?

options.text: No specific actions are required.
Stow the service trolley and secure the cabin.
Ask passengers how they feel.
Sit down and fasten seat belts.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

An aircraft is operating a flight within NAT HLA when the pilot notices a message appear on the EFIS. The message is regarding the navigation accuracy and the pilot then enters the “position monitor” page available via the FMS to investigate further. As a result of the information they read on the screen of the CDU, what, if any, actions should the pilots take?

options.text: Revert to dead reckoning navigation starting at the last plotted position since all navigation systems have failed and show incorrect information.
Immediately descend to exit the NAT HLA since the navigation accuracy is uncertain and separation to adjacent traffic CANNOT be assured.
Identify and isolate the faulty system and establish whether it is possible to continue the flight as originally planned but with reduced redundancy.
Notify ATC of the total navigation system failure and continue the flight while monitoring the performance of the faulty FMS in backup mode.

variant.question:
An operator shall not operate an aeroplane first issued with an individual Certificate of Airworthiness on or after 1 April 1998, which has a maximum certificated take-off mass over 5700 kg, unless it is equipped with a cockpit voice recorder which records:

1 – Voice communications transmitted from or received on the flight deck by radio   
2 – The aural environment of the flight deck   
3 – The cabin attendants communications in the cabin using the aeroplane\`s interphone system   
4 – Voice communications of flight crew members on the flight deck using the aeroplane\`s interphone system   
5 – Voice or audio signals identifying navigation or approach aids introduced into a headset or speaker   
6 – Voice communications of flight crew members on the flight deck using the public address system, if installed

The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
In accordance with the OPS regulations, a single deck aeroplane, equipped with an approved seating capacity of 71 seats and carrying passengers, must be equipped with at least:

options.text: 2 megaphones if there are more than 31 passengers on board.
2 megaphones.
1 megaphone.
3 megaphones.

variant.question: What is the primary purpose of allowing aircraft to conduct oceanic flight in the NAT HLA to fly self-selected lateral offsets (SLOP)?

options.text: To alert air traffic controllers about navigation equipment malfunctions.
To mitigate against collision risk.
To allow faster aircraft to overtake slower preceding aircraft.
To reduce pilot error after manual reversion.

variant.question: The abbreviation "MASPS" stands for..

options.text: Mobile Aerodrome Systems Performance Standards.
Minimum Aviation System Performance Standards.
Multi Aircrew Standardisation and Proficiency Specification.
Minimum Airspace Separation Procedures Specification.

variant.question: A flight is scheduled to operate in Polar regions. Why is the compass not being used in such locations?

options.text: The vertical field strength is too weak.
Due to the fluctuating field strength.
Due to the lack of GPS signals.
The horizontal field strength is too weak.

variant.question: To support air-ground ATC communications in the North Atlantic region, how many HF frequencies have been allocated and what frequency bands do they cover?

options.text: 24, covering 2.8 to 1.8 Mhz.
20, covering 18 to 24 Mhz.
24, covering 2.8 to 18 Mhz.
18, covering 2.4 to 18 Mhz.

variant.question: Choose the correct statement in regard to HLA Routes T16 and T213:

options.text: They are not part of the OTS but require LRNs.
They are random routes and require 2 LRNs.
They are not part of the OTS but require 2 LRNs.
They are random routes and require 1 LRNs.

variant.question: What is the General Concept of the NAT in-flight contingency procedures? Whenever operationally feasible:

options.text: To offset 5 nm left or right of the cleared route and descend below FL290, then descend 300 ft if right of track and climb 300 ft if left of track, maintain offset until an ATC clearance received.

To offset 5 nm left or right of the cleared route and descend below FL290, then maintain a 500 ft vertical offset until an ATC clearance received. If not descending below FL 290, establish a 500 ft vertical offset.

To offset 5 nm left or right of the cleared route and descend below FL290, then maintain a 300 ft vertical offset until an ATC clearance received. If not descending below FL 290, establish a 300 ft vertical offset.

To offset 15 nm left or right of the cleared route and descend below FL290, then maintain a 500 ft vertical offset until an ATC clearance received. If not descending below FL 290, establish a 500 ft vertical offset.

variant.question: An aeroplane which has a maximum certificated take-off mass over 5700 kg, shall be equipped with a cockpit voice recorder capable of retaining information recorded during at least the last:

options.text: 30 minutes or 1 hour of its operation, depending upon the date of the first issue of its individual Certificate of Airworthiness.
30 minutes or 2 hours of its operation, depending upon the date of the first issue of its individual Certificate of Airworthiness.
25 hours of its operation.
10 hours of its operation.

variant.question:
Area Navigation (RNAV) and Required Navigation Performance (RNP) are fundamentally similar but they differ in the requirements for on-board performance monitoring and alerting. Despite the differences in the requirements, renaming RNP routes to RNAV routes would incur huge costs.

According to ICAO Doc 9613, which RNP designation does RNAV 10 retain?

An aeroplane is flying along airway T16 within the NAT HLA and is communicating with Shanwick Oceanic control using CPDLC. When passing GONAN, the CPDLC connection is automatically transferred to Santa Maria Oceanic control. What is correct?

options.text: The pilot does NOT need to take any further action once the CPDLC connection with Santa Maria Oceanic control is established.
The pilot is then required to perform a CPDLC facility notification/log-on with Santa Maria, to acknowledge the automatic transfer.
The pilot is then required to contact Santa Maria Oceanic control using VHF radio in the 118.000 MHz to 136.975 MHz frequency band.
The pilot is then required to establish contact with Santa Maria Oceanic control using HF radio in the 2.8 MHz to 18 MHz frequency band.

variant.question: What’s a requirement to operate in NAT HLA airspace?

options.text: Both the plane and flight crew must be ETOPS compliant.
The plane must be ETOPS compliant.
The crew must be ETOPS trained.
The crew must have had training.

variant.question: An aeroplane enroute to the oceanic entry point BEGAS receives an Oceanic Clearance to enter via point BERUX. The pilot of the aeroplane must ..

options.text: Turn towrds BERUX 5 minutes before reaching BEGAS
Programme the FMS to fly direct to BERUX from the waypoint BEGAS
Fly to BEGAS, and when reaching BEGAS fly on to BERUX
Request and obtain a re-clearance from ATC to fly to BERUX

variant.question:
An aircraft is flying from London, Heathrow, UK to New York, JFK, USA and is within the NAT High Level Airspace at FL 360\. A hydraulic warning light has come on, which may necessitate a change of level. The in-flight contingency procedure requires an offset from the assigned route.

If prior clearance cannot be obtained, what would be the initial action?

options.text: A turn to the right of track of at least 45° towards the nearest alternate, which is Keflavik, Iceland.
A turn to the left or right of track by at least 45° and immediately initiate a descent to a lower level.
A turn to the right of track of at least 30° towards the nearest alternate, which is Keflavik, Iceland.
Turn to the right of track in order to avoid any nearby traffic, which would follow the Strategic Offset Procedure (SLOP).

variant.question: When shall crews report to ATC deviations from the assigned FL, when operating in the NAT HLA?

options.text: 500 ft or more.
300 ft or more.
200 ft or more.
100 ft or more.

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, the minimum number of crash axes or crowbars on board an aeroplane, whose maximum approved passenger seating configuration is more than 200, is:
A pilot qualified for single pilot commercial operations both on land and sea is joining a CAT operator. How many types of aircraft can this pilot operate commercially?

options.text: One reciprocating engine aircraft type.
One reciprocating engine aircraft type and variant (sea only).
Two reciprocating engine aircraft types or variants.
Three reciprocating engine aircraft types or variants.

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, the correct definition of Window Of Circadian Low (WOCL), is the period between:

options.text: 02.00 hours and 05.59 hours.
00.00 hours and 06.59 hours.
02.00 hours and 04.59 hours.
22.00 hours and 07.59 hours.

variant.question: You are close to your stall buffet boundary and you encounter Severe turbulence. You need to deviate less than 5 NM from your originally cleared track. You are flying in NAT airspace and are unable to establish communications with ATC. What should be the procedure?

options.text: Turn with a maximum bank of 30 degrees and maintain 500 ft clearance.
Maintain track and descend as soon as possible maintaining 300 ft clearance.
You must fly the turbulence penetration speed as deviation is not permitted with no ATC clearance.
Maintain the assigned flight level.

variant.question:
Put in order the action of a pilot who has to divert to Azores within the NAT:

1\. divert towards Azores   
 2\. fly 5 NM parallel offset   
 3\. fly 500’ above or bellow
The requirements for position plotting in the NAT HLA are:

options.text:
1\. Draw the intended route on a chart and check for gross errors; and   
 2\. Regularly plot the aircraft's position during the sortie using the FMS along track and cross track outputs.

1\. Highlight only Blue Spruce or Three Sisters routes; and   
 2\. Only plot positions derived from ground based navigation aids.

1\. Draw route as planned; and   
 2\. Plot only positions confirmed by VOR/DME or DME / DME.

1\. Draw the intended route on a chart and check for gross errors; and   
 2\. Regularly plot the aircraft's position during the sortie as a navigational cross check.

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, for turbine-engined aeroplanes with a maximum certificated take-off mass over 5700 kg, flight data recorders shall be capable of retaining the data recorded during at least the last:

options.text: 30 hours of operation.
10 flights.
25 hours of operation.
25 flights.

variant.question: In case of total loss of communications, if an aircraft operating in MNPS airspace is unable to continue its flight in accordance with its ATC clearance, it must offset from the assigned route by 5 NM and climb by 1 000 ft or descend by 500 ft to a level which differs from those normally used if flying:

options.text: at FL430.
below FL410.
at FL410.
above FL410.

variant.question:
When flying westbound along an OTS at FL380 across the North Atlantic with an oceanic clearance, you have to deviate 10 NM south of your intended track due to bad weather.

What do you do?

options.text: Descend 300 ft.
Climb 1 000 ft.
Descend 1 000 ft.
Climb 300 ft.

variant.question: An aeroplane is planned to be flown commercially in the North Atlantic High Level Airspace (NAT HLA). The aeroplane is equipped with two Global positioning System (GPS) Long Range Navigation Systems (LRNSs). The use of these LRNSs for operation in the NAT HLA is approved by:

options.text: The state of registry
IATA
ICAO
EASA

variant.question: When leaving the MNPS oceanic control area for a domestic controlled area, the pilot has to:

options.text: take any Mach number.
take the Mach number specified in his initial flight plan.
take the Mach number provided for this type of flight by his airline.
maintain the Mach number previously assigned up to the last position shown in the oceanic clearance.

variant.question: A pilot requests an oceanic clearance: "ABC 123 request Oceanic Clearance. Estimating Renso at 8:31\. Request Mach 0.80, FL320, second choice track Bravo." Is this oceanic request correct?

options.text: Yes, because flight level, Mach number and route are contained.
No, because there is no first choice track contained.
Yes, because identification, Mach number, flight level, and ETA over a specific point is contained.
No, because there is no maximum acceptable flight level contained.

variant.question: When following an OTS in the NAT HLA and no revised clearance from ATC has been received, the correct course of action for an aircraft deviating from track by less than 5 NM is:

options.text:
1\. Establish Comms with other aircraft on 121.5 Mhz or 123.45 Mhz and state intentions.   
 2\. Watch for conflicting traffic, visually and by ACAS.   
 3\. Turn on all exterior lights.   
 4\. When deviating less than 5 NM then descend 500 ft below assigned FL.

1\. Establish Comms with other aircraft on 121.5 Mhz or 123.45 Mhz and state intentions.   
 2\. Watch for conflicting traffic, visually and by ACAS.   
 3\. Turn on all exterior lights.   
 4\. When deviating less than 5 NM then descend 300 ft below assigned FL.

1\. Establish Comms with other aircraft on 121.5 Mhz or 123.45 Mhz and state intentions.   
 2\. Watch for conflicting traffic, visually and by ACAS   
 3\. Turn on all exterior lights.   
 4\. When deviating less than 5 NM then maintain assigned FL.

1\. Establish Comms with other aircraft on 121.5 Mhz or 123.45 Mhz and state intentions.   
 2\. Watch for conflicting traffic, visually and by ACAS.   
 3\. Turn on all exterior lights.   
 4\. When deviating less than 5 NM then climb 300 ft above assigned FL.

variant.question: Which of these options is the basic definition of Required Navigation Performance (RNP)?

options.text: A statement of the navigation performance necessary during flight tests for a new aircraft type.
A statement of the navigation performance necessary for operation within a defined airspace.
A statement of the navigation performance required during a pilot skill test.
A statement of the navigation performance required when installing a new navigation aid on the ground.

variant.question: During a transatlantic flight in the NAT airspace, an operational check of the SELCAL equipment must be done:

options.text: As soon as possible after entering the NAT region.
On ATC request only.
Within 15 minutes after crossing the oceanic airspace boundary.
at or before initial entry into oceanic airspace.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying on route T9 and one of its two FMSs used for LRNS fails. What can the aircraft do?

options.text: It must carry out the contingency procedure and divert.
It can continue on T9 as only one LRNS is required.
It must inform ATC and ask for a re-routing.
It must descend below FL 285.

variant.question: You want the IRS to be as accurate as possible when in NAT HLA airspace. When do you align the IRS?

options.text: As soon as the first person enters cockpit.
When you release the parking brake.
When the engines are on.
40 min before oceanic entry.

variant.question: An aircraft has departed from Dublin on a transoceanic flight to Montreal. Prior to entering NAT HLA (High Level Airspace) at level flight, the flight crew performs a final confirmation of the aircraft systems serviceability and checks the two primary altimeter readings. Unless otherwise specified, within how many feet of each other must the altimeter readings be?
When should pilots request their Oceanic Clearance?

options.text: At least 40 minutes prior to the Oceanic entry point ETA.
At least 20 minutes prior to the Oceanic entry point ETA.
At or prior the Oceanic entry point.
At the Oceanic entry point.

variant.question: The abbreviation MNPS stands for:

options.text: Minimum Navigation Performance Specification
Modern Navigation Performance System
Main Navigation Performance System
Maximum Navigation Performance Specification

variant.question: Aircraft may operate in MNPS airspace along a number of special routes if the aircraft is equipped with at least:

options.text: three Inertial Navigation System (INS).
two Inertial Navigation Systems (INS).
two independent Long Range Navigation Systems (LRNS).
one Long Range Navigation System (LRNS).

variant.question: The co-pilot is the Pilot Flying (PF) during an approach to an unfamiliar aerodrome. Weather conditions are VMC. While joining the Final Approach segment the Ground Proximity Warning System sounds. The co-pilot, as the PF of the aircraft, should..

options.text: start looking outside the flight deck to identify the obstacle or terrain causing the alert, to visually avoid it.
continue the approach. The decision for corrective actions rests with the Commander of the aircraft.
take immediate corrective action to establish safe flight conditions.
change the lateral track of the aircraft by at least 15 degrees left or right, but maintain the vertical path.

variant.question: A CAT operator is notified by one of their pilots of a data inconsistency that has been discovered in the aeronautical database installed in one of their aeroplanes. The operator should...

options.text: do nothing, such errors have NO practical impact and will be corrected with the next scheduled update.
report the issue to the competent authority.
correct the error in the database.
report the issue to the database provider.

variant.question: A pilot is flying an aircraft in the NAT HLA along the westbound Organised Track System (OTS) and intends to follow an OTS Track for its entire length. If the aircraft is properly equipped, the pilot may plan to cruise at any..

options.text: even level between FL285 and FL420 inclusive.
odd level between FL285 and FL420 inclusive.
of the levels published for that track in the current NAT track message.
of the levels between FL285 and FL420 inclusive, excluding FL390, which is reserved for State aircraft.

variant.question: According to ICAO and for the purposes of consistency with the PBN concept, which navigation specification is to be referred to as RNAV 10, because a change in the actual designation would be too expensive and not cost-effective.

options.text: RNP 10
RNP 4
RNP 0.1

variant.question: An oceanic ATC clearance includes..

options.text: Mach number and flight level.
HF frequency in use and flight level.
route, flight level and Mach number.
HF frequency in use and route.

variant.question: What is required when flying in the NAT HLA airspace?

options.text: Crew must undertake training programme.
ETOPS crew.
ETOPS aircraft.
ETOPS crew and aircraft.

variant.question: At which levels may Reduced Vertical Separation Minimum (RVSM) be used within the NAT region?

options.text: Between FL270 and FL410 inclusive.
Above FL 245.
Between FL290 and FL410 inclusive.
Between FL290 and FL450 inclusive.

variant.question: An aircraft flying in NAT HLA in Shanwick and is in active contact via CPDLC. During crossover to Santa Maria, the crew automatically connects via CPDLC with Santa Maria. Which of the following is correct?

options.text: Contact Santa Maria via radiocommunication, using HF radio in the 2.8 MHz to 18 MHz frequency band.
You need to contact/log on with Santa Maria to confirm automatic change.
The pilot is then required to contact Santa Maria Oceanic control using VHF radio in the 118.000 MHz to 136.975 MHz frequency band.
Do nothing as contact via CPDLC is transferred automatically.

options.text: subject to an optional clearance depending on the type of flight (scheduled or not)
subject to a clearance, only for flights in OTS system
subject to an oceanic clearance
subject to a clearance only if the flight route is changed

variant.question: Arriving at the entry point of MNPS airspace and not having yet received the oceanic clearance due to radio communications equipment failure, using the speed and level as contained in the filed flight plan, the crew shall:

options.text: set an offset of 30 nautical miles from the current flight plan.
divert to appropriate airport immediately.
carries out a holding pattern.
proceed via the filed flight plan route to landfall.

variant.question: A flight via the SHANNON-GANDER great circle with no MNPS certification can be planned:

options.text: at FL 290.
at FL 280 or less.
at a Mach number of 0.70 or less.
outside OTS validity hours.

variant.question: Navigation tasks at high latitudes may be complicated due to the very rapid changes, over small distances, in..

options.text: divergence of the meridians.
magnetic variation.
the INS rigidity in space.
compass deviation.

variant.question: According to OPS regulations, an operator shall not operate an aeroplane authorized to carry more than 19 passengers for which individual Certificate of Airworthiness was first issued before 01 July 2008, unless it is equipped with, at least:

options.text: one ELT of any type transmitting on 406 MHz
one survival ELT and life saving equipment
one automatic ELT or two ELT of any type
one automatic ELT and one ELT of any type

variant.question: An aircraft is flying from Vancouver, Canada to Paris, France. The selected route through the NAT HLA crosses Greenland and Iceland, where the Grid MORA is 14,200 ft. There is a minor problem with the pressurisation system, which necessitates an immediate descent to a lower level. What would be the initial action if prior clearance CANNOT be obtained?

options.text: Descend at a maximum rate to a lower level and turn right to be clear of any other traffic.
Leave the assigned route by turning at least 30 degrees away from the highest ground in order to maintain terrain clearance.
Turn at least 45 degrees to leave the assigned route, the direction of the turn to be decided by the nearest suitable alternate for diversion.
Start descending immediately to a lower level, then turn left or right to avoid any other traffic which would be following the Strategic Lateral Offset Procedures (SLOP).

variant.question:
Below is an extract from an aeroplane MEL concerning the operational procedure associated with the failure of one or two autopilots. The aeroplane is dispatched with one AUTOPILOT inoperative.

FLIGHT PREPARATION/LIMITATIONS.  
When one autopilot Is Inoperative:  
Maximum landing capability Is FAIL PASSIVE CAT 3.  
for aircraft with the RNP AR capability, RNP AR operations strictly below 0.3 NM are NOT permitted

When both autopilots are Inoperative:  
For aircraft with the RNP AR capability, RNP AR operations are NOT permitted.  
RUM operations are NOT permitted.  
Maximum landing capability Is CAT 1.

What is the effect on the RVSM capability of the aeroplane with one autopilot inoperative?

options.text: There Is NO effect.
RNP AR operations are NOT permitted.
The aeroplane is all passive RVSM compliant.
The flIght must be conducted outside of RVSM airspace.

variant.question: When considering lateral navigation requirements in the NAT HLA, which of the following may grant RNP 10 and RNP 4 aircraft approvals?

options.text: ICAO.
EASA.
IATA.
The state of registry.

variant.question:
In MNPS airspace, an aeroplane is flying the Strategic Lateral Offset Procedure (SLOP). The pilots should deviate from their track using the appropriate offsets:

1\. One mile to the right   
2\. Center line   
3\. One mile to the left   
4\. Two miles to the left   
5\. Two miles to the right

options.text: 4 and 5.
2 and 4.

variant.question:
